(촀\0Ah, that graceful ballerina of the

most elegant and lithe of dinosaurs.

cutest of all the Ichthyosaurs!\0\0(&촀\0What makes a large, sea-dwelling

dominated by those great orbs!

prey into a false sense of security...\0d

label: Fossil_00195
text:
(촀\0Ah, \0Mammoths\0￿, the bad boys—and
girls!—of the ancient-mammal world.
(2촀\0So woolly! So unkempt!
()촀\0They are, of course, most famous for
their size, which could be up to
13 tons for the largest males.(\0촀\0
But they were subject to no one's
rules, and some species were
(촀\0SMALLER than modern elephants!
(촀\0Scientists have pondered for years:
were mammoths the COOLEST of
all extinct species? Perhaps so!

(촀\0Hootie-hoo, \0Parasaurolophus\0￿!

serenaded the late Cretaceous!

label: Fossil_00210
text:
(촀\0Ahemn\0\0 Yes, you may not have heard
of \0Deinonychus\0￿, but you may have
heard of its cousin, the Velociraptor.
(촀\0Both were predators distinguished by
their frighteningly huge toe claws.
They also likely had feathers.
(&촀\0The main difference between them?
Size. 
\0(%촀\0\0Deinonychus\0￿ was about seven
feet tall and weighed 160 pounds.
(촀\0Little Velociraptor, on the other
wing, was a compact two feet tall
and weighed only about 33 pounds!
(촀\0I've heard that people meeting
celebrities are often surprised at
how short they are in person!

label: Fossil_00216
text:
(촀\0Good old \0Diplodocus\0￿—what would
we do without you? This stout fellow
embodied all the best in dinosaurs.
(4촀\0Those sturdy legs, that magnificent
tail, and, above all, that
extraordinary neck!
(촀\0Did you know that its center of
gravity was such that sitting up on
its hind legs was probably easy?
(!촀\0What's more, paired with its long
neck, this ability greatly increased
its reach for eating plants!
(2촀\0Best of all, \0Diplodocus\0￿ probably grew
its entire life, having no "adult size."

\0(촀\0Would that we were all so gifted!

()촀\0Ahem. Yes. The \0Spinosaurus\0￿ was a
very large, carnivorous dinosaur,

(촀\0Unlike its more famous cousin,

(+촀\0Personally, I am simply relieved that
it did not seek FLYING prey.

label: Fossil_00226
text:
()촀\0You can't talk about \0Stegosaurus
\0￿without talking about the distinctive
diamond-shaped plates on its back.
These plates, while made of bone,
(촀\0were not actually connected to the
animal's skeleton!
(촀\0They simply grew out from the skin,
remarkably enough, and were up to
two feet tall and similarly wide.
(&촀\0It's not clear exactly how the plates
were arranged or what they were for.
\0
(촀\0Yet more mysteries of the ancients!

text:
((촀\0As herbivores go, \0Triceratops\0￿ was
unusually well equipped for
combat, wot!
(촀\0Its three horns and impressive, bony
frill probably helped it fight off

()촀\0The frill may also have been involved
in temperature regulation, or else in
attracting mates.
(&촀\0Does it seem to you like virtually all
distinctive dinosaur features were for
body heat or attracting mates?

label: Fossil_00295
text:
(촀\0\02\0Ȁ촃Ammonites\0￿(%촀\0 were creatures that lived
before and all the way through the
age of dinosaurs!\0\0()촀\0Because different species lived at

label: Fossil_00296
text:
\0(2촀\02\0Ā촃Coprolites\0￿ are, in factn\0\0ehmn\0\0bits
of fossilizedn\0\0
\0feces.
\0( 촀\0 Hoo! Eww!
It's true!
(9촀\0It must be said they are also
astonishing treasure troves of
ancient information, eh wot!
(촀\0For example,
\0 the \02\0Ā촃coprolite\0￿ from
certain plant-eating dinosaurs has
been found to contain small pebbles.
This tells us that these dinosaurs,
\0(5촀\0
like many modern birds,
\0 ate rocks to
help grind the greens in their bellies.
(촀\0Indeed!
\0 Fossilized feces reveal not
only what food the dinos ate, but
how they digested it too. 
\0((촀\0Hoo knew?!

label: Fossil_00298
text:
(촀\0\02\0Ȁ촃Archaeopteryx\0￿'s feathers(%촀\0 led many
people to believe it was the
progenitor of the birds, eh wotn\0\0
('촀\0Sadly, further evidence indicates it's
likely not a direct ancestor—more an

\0 (촀\0And new relatives

label: Fossil_00300
text:
(촀\0\02\0Ā촃Dinosaur tracks\0￿(%촀\0 are fossilized

of the sea or on soft earth.

out the creature's size, distinctive
gait,
\0 and, 
\0shockingly,
\0 walking speed!\0\0(촀\0These trace fossils are like social-

label: Fossil_00301
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ȁ촃australopith\0￿, thought to be one
(%촀\0of the links between humans and
apes, emerged 4,000,000 years ago.
(촀\0They lived long ago, even before

so there are profound differencesn\0\0\0\0(\0촀\0Even so, it seems to me that you

label: Fossil_00302
text:
(촀\0This \02\0Ā촃shark-tooth pattern\0￿ comes from
the lower jaw of an ancient shark of
the genus Helicoprion.
(촀\0Its teeth seem to have grown in a
distinctive arrangement rather
disturbingly termed a "tooth-whorl."
()촀\0I say "seem" because shark skeletons
are made not of bone, but cartilage,
except for their teeth.
(촀\0Consequently, their bodies are never
preserved as fossils,
\0 and questions
about their jaws remain unanswered.
(촀\0The size and placement in the stone
of the shark's teeth
\0(촀\0 are actually the
only things we have to work with.
(촀\0Sometimes in research we must
maintain a stiff upper lip, 
\0(촀\0even in
the absence of a stiff lower jaw!

label: Fossil_00303
text:
\0(%촀\02\0Ā촃Trilobites\0￿ were ancient and extinct
before the dinosaurs ever appeared!
\0
(촀\0It boggles the mind!
\0 Hoo!
(촀\0They were also one of the most
successful classes of animal ever,
existing for over 300 million years.
(4촀\0Some 50,000 species have been
identified in sizes ranging from
three millimeters to over two feet!
(촀\0Alas, that is the very limit of my
enthusiasm for them, though—
\0K(*촀\0they look rather too much like bugs.\0d

label: Fossil_04651
text:
(촀\0\02\0Ȁ촃Anomalocaris\0￿ lived in the water

\0er,

(촀\0bulging eyes like an\0\0
\0dragonfly,

\0
"\02\0Ȁ촃anomalocaris\0￿" means

label: Fossil_04658
text:
(촀\0The \0Megaloceros \0￿was a relative of
the deer that lived during the Ice
Age, long after the dinosaurs.
(촀\0It was also known as "megaloceros
giganteus"n\0\0
\0(2촀\0which just means
"deer with large horns."
(촀\0True to their name, they were deer
with antlers spanning roughly 10
feet across! Imagine the majesty!
(촀\0While smaller than many dinosaurs,
they were nonetheless a very
charismatic example of megafauna.

label: Fossil_04662
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ā촃myllokunmingia\0￿!
\0( (%촀\0Said to be one
of the oldest fish-like animals,
it lived well before the dinosaurs.
()촀\0It was about an inch long
\0 and seems
to have had no lower jaw. 
\0(촀\0It is awe-
inspiring imagining such ancient life!
(촀\0There is much we still don't know.

\0((7촀\0We may yet discover even older

label: Fossil_04663
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ā촃eusthenopteron \0￿is famous
for being the link between fish and
land animals long before dinosaurs.
()촀\0It seems to have had strong fins
capable of pulling it around areas
where the water was shallow.
(1촀\0When most creatures lived in the
sean\0\0
\0((\0촀\0they dreamed of land.
\0 If not
(촀\0for them,
\0 we mightn't be here today!
(촀\0Imagine if we'd not left the oceansn\0\0
\0
(촀\0How might fashion and music be
different in an aquatic world?
(&촀\0How would we resolve differences?

\0\0K(촀\0Perhaps some sort of ink-squirting contest of
champions?\0d

label: Fossil_04664
text:
(촀\0The \02\0Ȁ촃acanthostega\0￿! 
\0((%촀\0Said to be
one of the earliest amphibians,
it existed well before dinosaurs.
()촀\0Because they lived as fish not long
before, they still had gills and very
webbed "hands."
(1촀\0To toss away the life they knew
and venture onto unknown landsn\0\0
\0
((촀\0they must have been very brave!
(촀\0Hmmn\0\0
\0(&촀\0 Does it still count as bravery
if you have no understanding of
what you're doing?

label: Fossil_04665
text:
(촀\0Ah, yes, the \02\0Ā촃juramaia\0￿: one of the
first mammals, 
\0and one of the few
to live alongside the dinosaurs!
()촀\0In order to hide from much larger
dinosaurs, it was less than four
inches long and quite unobtrusive.
(촀\0Some even theorize that these
mammals were nocturnal until
the dinosaurs went extinct.
(:촀\0They needed every advantage to live
among those behemoths. They were
nocturnal before it was cool!

text:
(촀\0\0Brachiosaurus\0￿, whose name means

(!촀\0Due to its long front legs and

(촀\0Alas, in order to support its large
size, it likely needed to eat more or
less every waking hour.

have been indeed!

(촀\0Good old \0Diplodocus\0￿—what would
we do without you? This stout fellow
embodied all the best in dinosaurs.
(4촀\0Those sturdy legs, that magnificent
tail, and, above all, that
extraordinary neck!
(촀\0Did you know that its center of
gravity was such that sitting up on
its hind legs was probably easy?
(!촀\0What's more, paired with its long
neck, this ability greatly increased
its reach for eating plants!
(2촀\0Best of all, \0Diplodocus\0￿ probably grew
its entire life, having no "adult size."

\0(촀\0Would that we were all so gifted!
